Talk about #ThrowbackThursday! The American Museum of Natural History unlocked thousands of old photos! Our favorite:﻿

Wondefully Architect Natural History Museum at London.﻿
Meer weergevenMinder weergeven · Vertalen

The Known Universe | American Museum of Natural History The Known Universe takes viewers from the Himalayas through our atmosphere and the inky black of space to the afterglow of the Big Bang. Every star, planet, and quasar seen in the film is possible because of the world's most complete four-dimensional map of the universe, the Digital Universe Atlas that is maintained and updated by astrophysicists at the American Museum of Natural History. The film, created by the Museum, was originally part of an exhibition, Visions of the Cosmos: From the Milky Ocean to an Evolving Universe, at the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan during 2010.
Data: Digital Universe, American Museum of Natural History Visualization Software: Uniview by SCISS
Director: Carter Emmart Curator: Ben R. Oppenheimer Producer: Michael Hoffman Executive Producer: Ro Kinzler Co-Executive Producer: Martin Brauen Manager, Digital Universe Atlas: Brian Abbott
Music: Suke Cerulo
Credit: American Museum of Natural History http://www.amnh.org

From our visit to the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History. See more of my photography at http://www.laurelwitting.com/ #museummondays #vacationphotos #smithsonian #naturalhistory #curiosities #oddities #bats #laurelwitting #photography ﻿

Beijing Museum of Natural History
The Beijing Museum of Natural History is located at 126, Tian Qiao Nan Street, Chong Wen District, Beijing, 100050, and is the most popular natural history museum in China. It was originally founded in 1951 as the National Central Museum of Natural History, and its name changed to the Beijing Museum of Natural History in 1962. The BMNH is the first large scale natural history museum created in China.
read more..http://goo.gl/pqea8O

National Museum of Natural History | Washington, DC
Washington, DC has no shortage of impressive indoor spaces. I continue my vertoramic march across Washington with this photo of my favorite Smithsonian museum.
Metadata: 11mm, f/2.8, 10 X 3-shot HDR images, ISO 800, WB = Auto, Nikon D300, Tokina 11-16mm, shot handheld
Panoramic (or vertoramic) stitching tutorial: http://www.brandonkopp.com/Blogger/Entries/2012/7/8_Panoramic_Stitching_Using_Photoshop_(My_Photography_Toolbox).html﻿

Meer weergevenMinder weergeven · Vertalen

Over 7,000 archival photographs, rare book illustrations, drawings, notes, letters, and Museum memorabilia that make up a vast visual record of the Museum’s expeditions, exhibitions, research, and collections are now available online through the new Digital Special Collections. Take a look around: http://bit.ly/1fb7TgC﻿

Mysterious prehistoric reptiles fly into New York's American Museum of Natural History
The exhibit runs April 2, 2014 through January 4, 2015 and explores the world of flying reptiles, the first back-boned animals to evolve powered flight.
More : http://artdaily.com/news/69252/Mysterious-prehistoric-reptiles-fly-into-New-York-s-American-Museum-of-Natural-History
Caption: Part of the exhibit called "Pterosaurs: Flight in the Age of Dinosaurs" are shown at the American Museum of Natural History in New York.
AFP PHOTO/Don Emmert.﻿
